conclusion: The ball is thrown vertically upward with an initial velocity v_0, and the acceleration due to gravity is g.
The ball is thrown from the midpoint between the point light source and the wall.
The time to reach the maximum height t_up is v_0/g.
The total time of flight t_total is 2v_0/g.
The light source is fixed, and the shadow moves along the wall as the ball moves vertically.
The shadow's velocity v_shadow is proportional to the ball's vertical velocity due to similar triangles.
At any time t, the ball's height y(t) is v_0 t - (1/2) g t^2.
The horizontal distance x_shadow of the shadow from the wall is d (y(t)/(d - y(t))).
Differentiating x_shadow with respect to time gives v_shadow = (d v_ball)/((d - y(t))^2).
At t = 0, the ball's initial velocity is v_0 and initial height y(0) = 0.
The initial velocity of the shadow is v_0/d.
